Yes, that's how I understand the Liang/Bracha paper you refer=
enced, and other stuff like the VM spec.  I've read that Liang/Bracha paper=
 several times in the past few years when I was trying to grok classloaders=
.

> May I submit that classes are dealt with using references, which are
>=
 themselves neither objects nor classes?  Oooo, this is tricky.

But that's=
 true of all reference types in Java at the language level.  A possible con=
fusion being that ClassLoaders maintain references to the Class objects of =
reference types they've loaded, so there's no correlation between the garba=
ge collection of object instances of a reference type and the garbage colle=
ction of the binary class definition of the reference type itself, which ca=
n only get collected when the ClassLoader that loaded the Class does.

Is i=
t clearer/more accurate to say that an instance of java.lang.Class is essen=
tially a *wrapper* to the JVM's internal representation to a reference type=
's definition (i.e., a lower-case 'class')?  I think that's closer to the t=
ruth.

Basically, you can't access any reference type definition directly i=
n Java except via reflective methods on an already loaded class or operatio=
ns on a not-yet-loaded class's binary definition.  If you change the bytes =
that make up a reference type's definition, then the type has to be loaded =
(if not yet loaded) or reloaded in a new ClassLoader, including all the usu=
al stuff the JVM does when loading a class (verify, link, resolve), which i=
s done in JVM C code (I've looked around in there a bit in the past).  Then=
, you can access that type's definition in a read-only manner via the java.=
lang.Class API.

> Part of the murkiness here is due to my peculiar experie=
nce: 
> I know that in reality Java at the JVM level is not a fully 
> obje=
ct-oriented language.

I doubt it's your fault.  There are a lot of overloa=
ded terms, like class/Class, and sloppy uses where we intend to mean someth=
ing else.  Tools like BCEL and common problems with ClassLoaders in tools l=
ike JUnit and J2EE application servers have really increased the numbers of=
 people who deal with this stuff in one way or another.
